document.title: Branch correlation measurements in an indoor raleigh fading channel for polarization diversity using a dual polarized patch antenna
document.authors: Hajian, M.; der Zwan, F.v.; Ligthart, L.P.
document.abstract: Spatial diversity techniques like polarization diversity, Space-Time Coding or Maximum Ratio Combining are advantageous if the received signals of the diversity branches are sufticiently uncorrelated. lndoor non-lineof-sight measurements were carried nut to study the cross-correlation between two received signals of orthogonal polarization using a dual linear polarized patch antenna. The antenna has been designed, built and measured at IRCTR. This paper gives the results of the channel measurements. It is concluded that received signals with orthogonal polarization in indoor Rayleigh fading channels have no significant envelope correlation.

document.title: Degradation of the signal-to-noise ratio in the bearnforming due to digital implementation
document.authors: Hattenberger, V.; Yide Wang; Toutain, S.
document.abstract: Implementing a beamforming algorithm in a digital signal processor using fixed-point arithmetic generates several errors which will cause a degradation of signal-to-noise ratio. In this paper, the degradation is analysed analytically by taking into acconnt all the quantization errors due to a digital implementation contrary to the classical analysis which considers only the signal and weight representation errors.

document.title: Another parameter representing QoS gain of MIMO systems
document.authors: Che, H.; Nassereddine, A.; Nikookar, H.; Prasad, R.; Ligthart, L.P.
document.abstract: Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) is a popular technology in wireless communications recently because it can take advantage of multipath and turn it into advantage. There have heen a lot of results about the gains that MlMO can achieve in terms of SNR gain and capacity gain. In the literature, SNR is the only parameter exploited to represent the Quality of Service (QoS) gain of MIMO over SISO systems. But we found out that t is notLenongh to present the QoS gain of MlMO systems. We introduce a Rician R factor gain of MIMO systems over SISO systems in order to make the parameters representing QoS complete. And we give the Rician K gain of three MIMO technologies by simulations. These results form the necessary database to make efficient use of MlMO systems.

document.title: Estimation of the direction of arrival of broadband signals using a single snapshot
document.authors: Fernandez-Recio, R.; Garcia-Castillo, L.E.; Sarkar, T.K.; Salazar-Palma, M.
document.abstract: Estimation of the Direction Of Arrival (DOA) of broadband signals is presented based on a single snapshot of data using an interpolation methodology. The goal is to simultaneously estimate the DOA of all the signals along with their respective frequencies of operation using a single snap shot of the voltages measured at the antennas. Numerical results are presented to illustrate the applicability of this novel methodology.

document.title: LEO satellite W-CDMA downlink pole capacity
document.authors: Ahmed, B.T.; Ramon, M.C.; Ariet, L.H.
document.abstract: The performance of downlink power control model, based on a n-th power distance law, is evaluated for LEO satellite W-CDMA systems. The downlink pole capacity using this model is given for voice and data services.

document.title: Correlation suppression performance for coherent signals in RD-SSP-MUSIC with a seven-element ESPAR antenna
document.authors: Hirata, A.; Taillefer, E.; Anono, T.; Yamada, H.; Ohira, T.
document.abstract: This paper clarifies correlation suppression performance of RD (ReactanceDomain)-SSP (Spatial smoothing Preprocessing) -MUSIC in a radio environment where two coherent signals with perfect correlation impinge on a seven-element circular ESPAR (Electronically Steerable Parasitic Array Radiator) antenna from various sets of DOAs (Directions-Of-Arrival). The RD-SSP-MUSIC scheme has been proposed for the ESPAR antenna to estimate the DOAs of coherent signals by F/B (Forward-Backward) SSP utilizing three pairs of diamond-shaped snharrays. Simulation results show that the SSPOOO, which is one of the F/B SSP of the ESPAR antenna, can obtain a lower correlation toward two signals from 100 degrees and 120 degrees, compared with the signals from 160 degrees and 180 degrees. On the other hand, the signals with DOAs of 160 degrees and 180 degrees are distinguished by the SSPO60. That is, the variance of an angular resolution on two coherent signals from close DOAs to a parallel sliding direction is compensated by another type of snbarray. Moreover, we have found that the smallest angular distance distinguishable by the SSPOOO is 18.0 degrees given by a set of8l.O degrees and 99.0 degrees.

document.title: Direction finding with superresolution using root implementation of eigenstructure techniques and joint estimation strategy
document.authors: Vasylyshyn, V.I.
document.abstract: In this paper the problem of direction of arrival estimation when using the uniform linear array is considered. In the wireless mobile communication such problem is individual or is of interest as a part of more general problem of estimation of the mobile channel directional structure. The root modification of recently proposed joint estimation strategy (JES) is presented. The essence of JES is to use the several eigenstructure-based estimators (estimator hank) for a given sample covariance or data matrix. Appropriately combining the results of these underlying estimators, JES improves the threshold performance. The modified Root-MUSIC algorithm and modified generalized Root-Min-Norm algorithms are used as underlying estimators. The proposed root implementation of JES provides computational saving and better threshold performance than spectral JES.

document.title: Baseband combiner for space diversity application: experimental results and a comparison with IF combiner
document.authors: Mandich, D.; Valtolina, R.
document.abstract: In the paper the basic structure of Alcatel high capacity STM-1 baseband combiner (applicable also for STM-0 applications) for space diversity application is described; its performances in term of signature are shown and compared with the ones of a traditional IF combiner, explaining how the former outperforms the latter. Moreover the result of extensive measurements, that have been carried out on a 10.5 GHz trial link in the northern of Italy during the summer months (that are the most affected by multipath fading), are reported. Comparison in term of outage between measured and predicted performances by theoretical models gives good agreement.

document.title: A 1.8-5.5 GHz integrated five-port front-end for wideband transceivers
document.authors: Rangel de Sousa, F.; Huyart, B.
document.abstract: Six and five-port direct conversion receivers have demonstrated being an interesting alternative since their design is simple and they can he calibrated to operate in a wide range of frequencies. We present in this paper a novel architecture based on the five-port principle suitable for direct up-and-down conversion between baseband and RF signals. In addition, a realization of the proposed architecture in GaAs for the 1.8 - 5.5 GHz band is described. The performance of the transceiver is demonstrated through measurement results.

document.title: Modeling indoor propagation using an indirect hybrid method combining the UTD and the FDTD methods
document.authors: Reynaud, M.; Guiffaut, C.; Reineix, A.; Vauzolle, R.
document.abstract: Classical theories such as the Uniform Theory of Diffraction (UTD) use analytical expressions for diffraction coefficients [l]. These methods are convenient for canonical problems for objects much greater than the wavelength and enable to rise in frequency. For more complex and smaller scattering structures, the rigorous methods like the Finite Difference Time Domain method (FDTD) is more adapted [2]. In this paper, we present an original approach, combining the advantages of these two complementary methods. So, the pmpagation channel can be accurately characterised.

document.title: CBQ-based call admission control for the WCDMA downlink in a multiservice context
document.authors: Chie Don; Hung-Ta Chang
document.abstract: This paper is aiming at the CBQ-based call admission control (CAC) for a WCDMA downlink in a multiservice context. A hierarchical link-sharing structure is used to express multiple link-sharing constraints on a radio downlink. All sharing connections on the Link are assigned to one of the leaf classes; the inferior classes are used to designate guidelines about bow 'excess' transmission power should be allocated. By fully exploiting the advantages of sharing 'excess' transmission power occurring at every inferior class in the hierarchical Link-sharing structure, the proposed CAC algorithm greatly improves the system performance.

document.title: Up-link throughput assessment in W-CDMA networks
document.authors: Maslanka, K.; Gajewski, P.; Sereda, W.
document.abstract: First Page of the Article

document.title: Design of a 2.4-GHz printed meander-line antenna for USB WLAN-card with notebook-PC housing
document.authors: Chuang, H.-R.; Kuo, S.-W.; Lin, C.-C.
document.abstract: In WLAN card design, the typical type is the PCMCIA WLAN card and many printed antennas have been reported for the PCMCIA card applications [I-31. Currently there is a miniaturized WLAN card (about the same size of the small portable RAM disk) which uses the USB connector to be plugged into the notebook PC. The USB connector can be bended and hence the antenna on the WLAN card can have different position and orientation. This paper presents a 2.4-GHz meander-line printed antenna for WLAN applications. The HFSS 3-D EM simulator is used for design simulation. The antenna is fabricated on a double-sided FR-4 printed circuit board for experimental measurements. The effect of the notebook housing on the USB-WLAN card is also studied.

document.title: Design of driver amplifiers in sice technology for 5 GHz WLAN applications
document.authors: Alimenti, F.; Palazzari, V.; Roselli, L.; Scorzoui, A.
document.abstract: First Page of the Article

document.title: An induvfively loaded PIFA for automotive applications
document.authors: Chakam, G.-A.
document.abstract: A side grounded and fed PIFA has been designed and investigated for automotive applications. The behaviour of the resonance frequency and the impedance as a fimction of a design parameter has been analysed. For the optimised set of design parameters the radiation pattern as well as the gain of the antenna have been evaluated. Further results will be presented.

document.title: Multi-path delay measurement based on five-port discriminator
document.authors: Van Yem Vu; Braga, A.J.; Begaud, X.; Huyart, B.
document.abstract: A new system based on five port discriminator which measures multi-path delays through the use of the frequency sounding technique is presented. The multi-path delays are estimated by using not only Inverse Fast Fourier Transform OFFT) but also the high resolution method Multiple Signal Classification (MUSIC) when it is associated with Spatial Smoothing (SS) method. In addition, we also show that it is capable of estimating the time delay and direction of arrival (DoA) simultaneously using five-port technique.

document.title: Combination of block diagonalization and THP transmit filtering for downlink beamforming in multi-user MIMO systems
document.authors: Stankovic, V.; Haardt, M.; Fuchs, M.
document.abstract: In this paper we compare three spatial multiplexing techniques suitable for the use in the multi-user multiple-input multiple-output (MU MIMO) downlink. The first one is a linear method called bloek diagonalization (BD) and is based on the singular value decomposition (SVD). The second one is Tomlinson-Harashima Precoding Transmit Wiener Filtering (THF' TxWF). The third one is a new technique that combines the advantages of BD and THP transmit filtering. We investigate the influence of different degrees of channel state information at the transmitter on their bit error performance. We show that the combination of THP TxWF for single-antenna nsers and BD for multiple-antenna nsers can improve the overall system performance and has better bit error performance with perfect as well as imperfect channel state information at the transmitter.

document.title: Improvement of planar antenna efficiency when integrated with a millimetre-wave photonic crystal
document.authors: Burns, G.W.; Thayne, I.G.; Arnold, J.M.
document.abstract: In this work a silicon-based coplanar waveguide (CPW)-fed slot dipole antenna has been integrated with a silicon micromachined three-dimensional woodpile photonic bandgap crystal (PBG) in the W-band regime (67-110GHz). A slot dipole antenna optimired for operation at 94GHz shows significant radiation through the subsirate as expected. Combination of the slotline antenna and the PEG shows a strong interaction between the two, with complete suppression of backside radiation. In addition, the resonant frequency of the 94 G l h antenna was found to he dependent on its positioning on the PEG. Also shown in this work is the experimental optimisation of the slotline dipole geometry to produce resonant behaviour at 94 GHz when placed on the PBG. As a consequence, the radiation efficiency of the combined antennalPBG is significantly enhanced at 94 GHz.

document.title: Solid state power amplifier (SSPA) nonlinearity effects on quadri-phase shift keying modulation
document.authors: Dudak, C.; Arzu Tuncay Koc; Sencer Koc
document.abstract: In this paper, qnadri-phase shift keying (QPSK) and ofiset QPSK (OQPSK) modulation formats?? performances are comparatively examined for a specific power amplifier (PA) nonlinearity model. For this purpose, a new descriptive evaluation parameter, r, is introduced instead of conventional input oue-dB compression point (PIdBb)a ckoff. Related bit error ratio (BER) -simulated in an AWGN channel with a golden unit receiver model- and EVM (Error Vector Magnitude) discussions are made.

document.title: ECWVT 2004 Technical Programme Commiftee
document.abstract: Provides a listing of current committee members.

document.title: [Blank page]
document.abstract: This page or pages intentionally left blank.

document.title: The effect of source pulse shape on the energy and correlation patterns of uwb antennas
document.authors: McLean, J.S.; Sutton, R.; Foltz, H.
document.abstract: Three useful indicators of time domain and ultra-widehand antenna performance are the energy gain, the correlated energy gain, and the correlation coeflicient. The energy gain indicates how much of the energy incident on the antenna??s input port is radiated, the correlated energy gain gives an indication of how much of the incident energy is radiated in a form correlating with a particular template function, and the correlation coeffirient indicates how much the pulse distortion due to an antenna vanes with direction and is important because, even with adaptive equalization, it is not possible to simultaneously correct for direction-dependent distortion dynamically. We examine the effect of input pulse shape on the energy and correlation patterns of P typical broadband antenna suitable for use with UWB communication systems, a hiconical dipole. For a given antenna these patterns depend on both the input pulse shape and the source impedance. We present results for different input pulse shapes including baseband Gaussian pulses and N-cycle sinusoids with Gaussian envelopes. Because the spectral content of each pulse is different, the energy, correlated energy and correlation coeflieient patterns are unique for each pulse shape.

document.title: Novel block error rate model for rayleigh and sub-rayleigh fading channels
document.authors: Subotic, V.; Primak, S.L.
document.abstract: A novel method to estimate block error rates (BLER) in the Rayleigh and sub-Rayleigh fading channels is proposed. The suggested model is based on a finite state Markov chain. The proposed model is usable over a wide range of fading rates and is analytically tractable. The general analytical results are specialized to the case of differential phase shift keying (DPSK) and to the case of Jakes?? fading spectrum. The validity of the proposed model is confirmed by extensive simulation results.

document.title: The linear theory and engineering design of the phase invariant controlled attenuator
document.authors: Stoukatch, O.V.
document.abstract: On the base of the linear system theory a condition for minimum of the phase shift from attenuation in a voltage controlled attenuator (VCA) is founded. The base structure of the VCA is investigated. It is shown that fulfillment of the invariance condition provide a theoretically minimum of phase shift. For example, the paper disclosed details of the new attenuator design and discuss its performance. Its main difference from known consists in ultra broadband feature and large range of attenuation where minimum of the phase shift is reached at regulation. As a result of optimization, the correcting circuit parameters and adjusting parameters of diodes are founded.

document.title: Microwave applications of advanced semiconductor technologies
document.authors: Mertens, R.P.; De Raedt, W.; Carchon, G.; Tilmans, H.A.C.; Germain, M.
document.abstract: New semiconductor technologies, used in passive microwave applications, allow the integration of passives with high quality factors and the fabrication of novel RFMEMS components for switches and tunable capacitors and resonators. The use of these technologies results in a strong reduction of the sue and the power consumption of wearable microwave systems. The scaling of silicon transistors, following Moore's law, results in RF-CMOS devices approaching the performance of 111-V and SiGe devices but at a considerably lower cost and much higher integration capability. The introduction of GaN based technologies offering new possibilities in the field of power microwave devices is discussed.

document.title: A tight upper bound on the average mutual information in correlated rayleigh fading MIMO channels
document.authors: Mikas, F.; Salo, J.; Vainikainen, P.
document.abstract: We derive a tight upper bound on the average mutual information in Rayleigh distributed channels with spatial Correlation among antenna elements in transmitter and receiver arrays. The derivation of the upper bound is based on calculation of expected values of elementary symmetric functions of complex Gaussian matrix quadratic forms. It can be used for arbitrary SNR, arbitrary number of antenna elements and arbitrary spatial Correlation matrix that can be presented as a Kronecker product of transmitter and receiver correlation matrices. Using the upper bound it is simple to evaluate how the mutual information depends on correlation among elements in transmitter and receiver arrays.

document.title: Table of contents
document.abstract: Presents the table of contents of the proceedings.

document.title: Wireless system validation using VHDL-AMS behavioral antenna models: radio-frequency identification case study
document.authors: Khouri, R.; Beroulle, V.; Vuong, T.-P.; Tedjini, S.
document.abstract: In order to generate a first-time right design, system level modeling and simulation is a must. Thus, functional validation of integrated wireless systems requires the development of antenna models compatible with the microelectronic design tools. This paper presents the first VHDLAMS model of a wireless system that includes an RF link. Firstly, a behavioral model of a simple antenna is presented, then, a complete RFID system behavioral model is described at the system level. Finally, some examples of system simulation are presented in order to demonstrate the interest of our approach.

document.title: A CPW-fed horn-shaped slot array antenna for 5 GHz WLAN access point
document.authors: Shih-Yuan Chen; Powen Hsu
document.abstract: A 6-element horn-shaped slot array antenna fed by a coplanar waveguide is proposed to possess a wide impedance bandwidth and stable radiation characteristics simultaneously. A prototype array is designed and implemented for the 5-GHz WLAN access points. The measured 10-dB return loss bandwidth is 19.5% (5.14-6.25 GHz), and the in-band maximal antenna gains lie in the range of 8.6-10.7 dBi. The measured radiation patterns are shown to be satisfactory across the entire operating band 5.150-5.825 GHz for both the IEEE 802.11s and the HIPERIAN/2 systems.

document.title: The effect of antenna and pulse waveform on ultra wide band link budget with impulse radio transmission
document.authors: Irahhauten, Z.; Yarovoy, A.; Nikookar, H.; Janssen, G.J.M.; Ligthart, L.P.
document.abstract: this paper, a link budget calculation for the Ultra Wide Band Impulse Radio (UWB-IR) transmission is evaluated. The novel link budget expression is derived and the impact of the antenna gain as well as the waveform of the generator ootput on the received voltage is investigated. UWB time domain measurements were performed to validate the link budget model. Results can be used in the design and coverage of UWB wireless communication systems.

document.title: A practical medium access scheme for wireless ad hoc networks employing ESPAR antennas
document.authors: Lenoble, M.; Hunziker, T.; Aono, T.; Ohira, T.
document.abstract: Cochannel interference limits the capacity of wireless ad hoc networks. Adaptive antennas can mitigate cochannel Further interference by steering the beam in an appropriate direction. In this paper, we consider the application of an electronically steerable parasitic array radiator (ESPAR) antenna at every terminal in a packet-oriented wireless ad hoc network. A practical medium access scheme is used for the exchange of data packets where the terminals employ an opportunistic beamforming and refrainfrom sending a packet if too much interference is detected. The channels are modeled as multiple-inputlmultiple-output channels, being time invariant during a data packet transmission. In computer simulations, we investigate the transpnrt capacities that can be achieved with the proposed scheme and we analyze the transmission failure events.

document.title: Stat,e-of-the-art low loss, high isolation SP6T switch for handset applications
document.authors: Gotch, D.; Goh, T.; Jackson, R.
document.abstract: In this paper, the design and measurement of a low cost high performance SPLT gallium-arsenide switch are discussed. The design uses a novel approach to reduce receive path loss and to achieve >40dB TX-RX isolation. It is implemented with the Filtronic Compound Semiconductors 0.5um D-mode GaAs pHEMT process. The switch can be configured to connect different GSM / GPRS / EDGE 850 / 900 / 1800 / 1900 MHz transceivers to a common antenna and can be used in all systems requiring high power at control voltages down to 2.5V. The MMIC measures only 1.1 mm<sup>2</sup>. Transmit loss is less than 0.6 dB at 2 GHz, receive loss is less than 1 dB.

document.title: Experimental results of route diversity in WACnet (wireless ad hoc community network) based on espar antenna and 802.11b ad hoc system
document.authors: Watanabe, M.; Tanaka, S.
document.abstract: In the application of ITS inter-vehicle communications, the influence of multipaths should he considered due to the effect of reflection from the mad surfaces. According to the traditional pmcessing, which ovoids the influence of multipaths, space diversity technique is often applied with two or more antemas of different height. By using ad hoc network technology to avoid the influence of multipaths, it is possible to apply the mute diversity technique with the multihop communications. This paper describes fundomental measurement data of reflection characteristics on asphalt surfaces in the 2.4-GHz bond , the experimental results of spare diversity and mute diversity on the road when using WACNet (Wireless Ad hoc Community Networks) based on the ESPAR antenna[l] and 802.11b [2] ad hoc system.

document.title: An integrated CMOS interference canceller for MIMO systems
document.authors: Gebara, E.; Tentzeris, M.M.; Laskar, J.
document.abstract: In this work, we present for the first time the theory and CMOS prototype for a interference canceller that improves the signal integrity and radiated pattern of closely spaced antennas for MIMO systems. The theory and prototype have been evaluated in a WLAN testhed demonstrating improvements of 3 to 4 dB in maximum radiated power. This improvement translates into 50-80 YO improvement in transmission distance, 40% reduction in power and lox improvements in BER

document.title: High speed millimeter wave five-port receiver
document.authors: Chakra, S.A.; Huyart, B.
document.abstract: This paper presents a broadband millimeter wave receiver. It proposes a new direct down conversion technique and its advantages using five-port system. A brief study of five-port is firstly presented. Then the functionality of this direct down conversion receiver concept is validated with a transmission system. This new technique is suitable for wireless local loop at 26GHz.

document.title: A new 5-GHz ISM band CMOS doubly balanced sub harmonic mixer for direct conversion receiver
document.authors: Upadhyaya, P.; Rajashekbaraiah, M.; Deukhyoun Heo; Yi-Jan Emery Chen
document.abstract: A new higb IIP2 low power doubly balanced subharmonic mixer for 5 GHz Industrial Scientific Medical (ISM) band direct conversion - zero IF receiver io an inexpensive 0.25-pm CMOS is presented. The sub-harmonic mixer, designed and fabricated, uses a power effcient IBX LO frequency generation scheme to overcome LO selfmixing problem common in conventional direct conversion receivers OCR). Simulated with 1% g, mismatch, 0.5% load mismatch and 2' LO phase error the mixer is able to achieve very good IIP<sub>2</sub> of 55.3 dBm, IIP, of -6.5 dBm, and voltage conversion gain of 8 dB while consuming less than 1.75 mA from a single 3V supply. The mixer also achieves input compression, Plde of -12 dBm and an overall double side baud noise figure of 5.96 dB. The proposed mixer takes up less than lmm' of silicon real estate including die pads. The performance of the designed and fabricated mixer is believed to have the best FOM (Figure of Merit) when considering IIP<sub>2</sub>, lIP<sub>3</sub>, P<sub>ldB</sub>, DSB NF, power consumption and gain performance parameter in 5 GHz ISM frequency band.

document.title: Beam-space processing with spatially interpolated wideband bearnformers for wideband direction-of-arrival estimation
document.authors: Tuan Do-Hong; Russer, P.
document.abstract: In this paper, we present a method for widehaud direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation, based on beam-space processing with spatially interpolated wideband heamformers (SIWB??s). The SIWB??s are designed to have frequency-invariant beam-response within a wide signal bandwidth. For wideband DOA estimation, these SIWB??s are used as spatial pre-processors transforming the widehand signals at the outputs of antenna array (element-space) into the heam-space signals prior to applying narrowband DOA estimation. The new SIWB-based method enhances the resolution of spectral estimation and reducing rootmean- square error of DOA estimation without increasing number of array elements. Furthermore, the proposed method is applicable for coherent sources without preliminary DOA estimates. The performance of the proposed method in comparison with the conventional methods is illustrated in simulation results. A preliminary analytical study of performance is also included.

document.title: List of technical reviewers
document.abstract: The conference offers a note of thanks and lists its reviewers.

document.title: Neural location detection in wireless networks
document.authors: Debono, C.J.; Buhagiar, J.K.
document.abstract: An innovative solution towards the implementation of wireless location detection using a modified self-organizing map is presented. The network translates the measured cell data of a radio environment onto a neumn hierarchy that is immune to environmental variations. Simulation results demonstrate the network??s ability to locate a mobile station within two meters in 94% of the cases.

document.title: High quality telephony over WLAN
document.authors: Lunn, A.; Kuhn, M.; Kuhn, M.; Ettefagh, A.; Cheetham, B.M.G.; Spegel, M.
document.abstract: In this paper we present a novel approach for merging the wireless telephony network with the wireless data network while retaining professional quality telephony and having little impact on the hest effort data network. The approach taken is to merge the upper layers of the DECT protocol stack with the WLAN physical and MAC layer technology, using a protocol adaptation layer (PAL). This merging of technologies, and so merging voice and data into a signal wireless network, is an enabling factor which will lead to innovative application in the field of wireless and mobile communications.

document.title: Cost-efficient design of 3D integrated RF and microwave modules for wireless communication systems
document.authors: Kangasvieri, T.; Jantunen, H.; Vahakangas, J.
document.abstract: This paper presents a novel efficient design approach for faster and more profitable development of highly integrated RF and microwave modules. To demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed design concept, a three-dimensionally (3D) integrated BGA filter module applicable in microwave link communications is designed at K-hand. Special emphasis is given to the design of various novel wideband module transitions with excellent transfer characteristic up to the millimeter-wave band. Finally, the design of a complete filter module with board-level BGA interconnections is validated with full-wave electromagnetic simulation of the entire packaging structure.

document.title: A high efficiency transmitter with a delta-sigma modulator and a noise cancellation circuit
document.authors: Matsuura, T.; Adachi, H.
document.abstract: We propose a new architecture for a transmitter with a delta-sigma modulator and a noise cancellation circuit. A data converter including a deltasigma modulator quantizes the magnitude of the baseband data, which comprises of the in-phase data, I, and the quadrature-phase data, Q. When considering a transmitter with a data converter, a bigb efliciency nonlinear power amplifier can be used, since the envelope of the input signal is quantized to single bit. Quantization noise due to the delta-sigma modulator is canceled by combining an error signal with the same amplitude and opposite phase, without the need for a high Q band-pass filter. Operation of the noise cancellation circuit is verified, and its efficiency is found to be 40%.

document.title: Improved UMTS base station transmitter featuring high efficiency and integrated analogue parts
document.authors: Bitzer, T.; Bohn, T.; Jacob, G.; Jacnecke, P.; Luger, J.; Pascht, A.; Schaepperle, J.; Schwoerer, G.; Strauss, J.
document.abstract: In this work, a transmitter for the application in UMTS base stations is presented. It is designed to process up to four neighbouring channels simultaneously. Compared to the state-of-the-art, it features a high effciency in the conversion of the supply power to the RF output power. For the analogue part of the transmitter, ASICs have been designed and fabricated using SiGe technology. In simulations using Agilent ADS, the functionality of the transmitter concept could be proved. Laboratory measurements have been done using a set-up consisting of evaluation hoards. With a power amplifier chain containing the latest LDMOS transistor generation, an RF output power of 40 W could he generated with a power amplifier effciency of30 % leading to a module effciency of 20 % while keeping the 3GPP ACLR specification.

document.title: Efficient antenna description for MIMO channel modelling and estimation
document.authors: Landmann, M.; Del Galdo, G.
document.abstract: Geometry-based MlMO channel modelling and a high-resolution parameter estimation are applications in which a precise description of the radiation pattem of the antenna arrays is required. In this contribution we propose an efficient representation of the polarimetric antenna response, which we refer to as the Effective Anerture Distribution Function (EADF. high-resolution parameter estimation are applications in which This reduced description permits us to efficiently interpolate thebeam pattem to gather the antenna response For an arbitrary direction in azimuth and elevation. Moreover, the EADF provides a continuous description of the array manifold and its derivatives with respect to azimuth and elevation. The latter is valuable for the performance evaluation of an antenna array as well as for gradient-based parameter estimation techniques.

document.title: Generalized orthogonal complementary codes for cdma wireless communications
document.authors: Bedzhev, B.Y.
document.abstract: The spread spectrum signals have large application in modern personal communication systems, but they must meet many requirements, addressed especially to theirs correlation properties. With regard to these requirements, recently some theorists proposed a new architecture for the next generation wideband wireless communications, based on so named Orthogonal Complementary Codes (OCC). The most distinguishable advantage of this architecture is possibility to operate without multiple access interference. As a result, the system capacity, secrecy, and electromagnetic Compatibility can he improved significantly. Due to positive features of the OCC in our paper we study the OCC in a wider frame, when phase manipulation could he arbitrary (i.e. not necessarily binary). On this base we prove a common method for creating of generalized OCC with unlimited code length and outline relations among some classes of signals with good correlation properties.

document.title: A highly miniaturized 2.4 GHz bluetootht/sup TM/ radio utilizing an advanced system-in-package technology
document.authors: Philippe, P.; Oruk, A.
document.abstract: A miniature Blnetooth radio, fully integrated in a 5x5 mm2 32-pin plastic package, is presented. The radio utilizes the novel Philips RF silicon-based System in Package technology (sbSIP) that enables the integration af all the passive components external to the radio transceiver IC into a silicon substrate. 10 spite of this extreme integration level and miniaturization, the radio achieves state-of-the-art performance with -85dBm sensitivity and 3 dBm output power for a power consumption of lOOmW under a 2.N supply.

document.title: Theoretical and practical investigation of a four-element smart antenna
document.authors: Piasecki, M.; Yashchyshyn, Y.; Modelski, J.
document.abstract: This paper reports on a successful attempt to develop and verify, through practical experiment, a complete model of a fewelement smart antenna utilising analogue beam-forming network (BFN). Various aspects of the hardware implementation of the BFN are analysed and a model of the smart antenna accounting for array mutual couplings and BFN scattering parameters is presented. Results of smart antenna performance in different electromagnetic conditions are shown.

document.title: Exploiting 70-90 GHz band for efficient gigabit wireless communications
document.authors: Frecassetti, M.; Mandich, D.; Pellizzoni, R.; Valtolina, R.
document.abstract: First Page of the Article

document.title: A simple high-data-rate architecture for multiple-access WLAN 60 GHz transceiver based on a LO phase noise cancellation technique
document.authors: Loyez, C.; Fryziel, M.; Boe, A.; Rolland, N.; Rolland, P.A.
document.abstract: A novel architecture for WLAN 60 GHz transceiver enables to cancel the phase-noise of local oscillators by transmitting an additional carrier without further degradation. Error-Vectorial-Magnitude and Carrier-to-Noise-Ratio measurements demonstrate the signal quality for a QPSK transmission with a 50 Mhps data-rate. Using MMlC VCOs, the performance of this very compact architecture is similar to that of a transceiver including ideal LOS. Further works are under development to improve the spectral efficiency of this topology and to reach potentialities of conventional FDMA systems.

document.title: Author index
document.abstract: The author index contains an entry for each author and coauthor included in the proceedings record.

document.title: A novel wideband pa behavioral model for wireless communication
document.authors: Yilong Shen; Tauritz, J.L.
document.abstract: A novel, local kernel concept for the behavioral modeling of power amplifiers is introduced. The model features high accuracy and simplicity in implementation. Unlike conventional black box models, this model relies on its own, specially designed, internal structure to enhance accuracy.

document.title: A new vector channel simulator for sub rayleigh fading
document.authors: Subotic, V.; Primak, S.L.
document.abstract: A novel vector channel simulator for sub- Rayleigh correlated fading is presented. The fading process is described as the product of a complex Gaussian and an exponentially correlated process produced by a noise-driven non-linear system. An isotropic scattering environment is assumed. The proposed model is studied using the example of Nakagami fading with m<l.

document.title: ESPRIT algorithm for a seven-element regular-hexagonal shaped ESPAR antenna
document.authors: Taillefer, E.; Chu, E.; Ohira, T.
document.abstract: A method to estimate direction of arrival (DoA) based on the ESPRIT algorithm is proposed for a 7-element regular hexagonal shaped electronically steerable parasitic array radiator (ESPAR) antenna. Tu verify the statistical performance of the proposed method, computer simulations on estimating DoA are conducted. The results show that the method can resolve up to three uncorrelated impinging signals incoming from different angles, and can provide an estimate with less than 0.65° of error for any DoA in the azimuth plane.

document.title: Impact of carrier frequency dependent power amplifier behavior on 802.11a WLAN system
document.authors: Liu, J.; Arslan, H.; Dunleavy, L.P.; Webster, A.; Paviol, J.
document.abstract: A revealing new study is presented on the impact of frequew-related Performance variation of Power amplifiers (PAS) for 802.11a WLAN systems. A look-up table (LUT) model that addresses such, so called, memory effects was developed for an example PA and used to study frequency dependent non-linear effects on WLAN system performance parameters, such as spectral reerowth (e.g. ACPR) and error vector magnitude (EVM). The results show significant frequency-dependent variations in these critical system parameters and underline the importance of memory-effect modeling for PAS used in OFDM WLAN systems.

document.title: Millimeter ultra wide band positioning system
document.authors: Bocquet, M.; Loyez, Ch.; Benlarbi-Delai, A.
document.abstract: "How to manage efficiently ad'hoc network?" could be the question that justify the present work. To maintain the network connectivity and optimize power consumption of mobile agents, localization and positioning are highly recommended. However with indoor communication and multipath contributions, budget error increases dramatically. Original solution performing Ultra Wide Band (UWB) approach is proposed. It uses millimeter multiband differential techniques improving TDOA methods.

document.title: Near field power density characterization of radio base station antennas using spherical harmonics optimization techniques
document.authors: Adane, Y.; Man-Fai Wong; Gati, A.; Dale, C.; Wiart, J.; Hanna, V.F.
document.abstract: Full characterization of real base station antennas can be achieved using spherical harmonics decomposition and optimization for the purpose of human exposure assessment. This paper emphasizes the application of the technique to postprocess near field measurements to derive the power density and the equivalent plane wave power densities as defined in international safety recommendations. DiNerences and Consequences in terms of compliance evaluation are discussed.

document.title: A new direct conversion receiver for WCDMA mobile applications
document.authors: Rezace, S.; Mohammadi, A.; Abdipour, A.
document.abstract: This paper presents an even harmonic direct conversion receiver for WCDMA applications. The receiver uses a very low noise LNA to provide the system gain and noise requirements. An even harmonic pumping mixer converts the RF signal to baseband signal. This cost effective mixer is well suited for DC Offset and even harmonics suppression. In order to decrease the receiver size, some techniques such as reduced size branch tine coupler and Wilkinson power divider with the lumped elements are used. The simulation results show that the proposed receiver specifications fully satisfy the requirements of the WCDMA receiver.

document.title: Automotive radar sensor with communication capability
document.authors: Winkler, V.; Detlefsen, J.; Siart, U.; Buchler, J.; Wagner, M.
document.abstract: In the last years short distance radar (SDR) systems for cars have been developed to the maturity phase. In order to use the sensors not only for comfort applications, hut also for safety applications, it is essential to guarantee a high degree of reliability under aU circumstances. One approach for increasing the reliability is to combine the data from different sensors, observing the complete car environment. A next step is to exchange sensor data between neighboured cars by a data Link. So it is necessary to establish intervehicle communcation (NC). This was the impulse to implement a system, which consists of a pulse radar at a center frequency of 24.125GHz and a communication transceiver. The mainlohe of the pulse radar occupies a bandwidth of 250MHz. The frequency hand of the transceiver, which is small compared to the pulse spectrum with its l.SMHz, is placed at the first sidelobe of the pulse spectrum. Because the bands are overlapping, the same RF frontend can he used, which decreases cost. The pulse radar is designed to allow simultaneous sensing over a range of nearly 40m and the communication link has a maximum range of 200m. In the following the basic concept and the signal processing of the radar and transceiver on Stratix-FPGAs (EPlS25F780C5) from ALTERAT<sup>TM</sup> are described.

document.title: A DSSS superregenerative receiver with tau-dither loop
document.authors: Moncunill-Geniz, F.X.; Pala-Schonwalder, P.
document.abstract: This paper describes a direct-sequence spread-spectrum superregenerative receiver using a PN code synchronization loop based on the tan-dither technique. The receiver minimizes overall complexity by using a single signal processing path for data detection and PN code synchronization. An analytical study on the loop dynamics is presented, and the conditions for optimum performance are examined. Experimental results in the 433 MHz European ISM band confirm the receiver ability to perform acquisition and tracking, achieving a sensitivity of -103 dBm and an input dynamic range of 65 dB.

document.title: 7th European Conference on Wireless Technology - Cover
document.abstract: Presents the front cover or splash screen of the proceedings.

document.title: Port decoupling for antennas with narrow element spacing
document.authors: Chaloupka, H.J.; Esser, D.; Wang, X.
document.abstract: Two-port antennas with narrow element spacing are in general governed by strongly correlated port patterns and gain reduction. Whereas the correlation between the port patterns can be controlled by the choice of the load impedance, gain reduction remains unavoidable with conventional antenna circuits. This paper demonstrates that cross-coupling between the feeding points of the elements can circumvent this problem.

document.title: ECWT2004 Steering Committee
document.abstract: Provides a listing of current committee members.

document.title: [Back cover]
document.abstract: Presents the back cover of the proceedings.

document.title: Quantization effects on the EVM in EDGE modulation standard
document.authors: Avitabile, G.; Lofu, N.
document.abstract: In this paper, qnadri-phase shift keying (QPSK) and ofiset QPSK (OQPSK) modulation formats?? performances are comparatively examined for a specific power amplifier (PA) nonlinearity model. For this purpose, a new descriptive evaluation parameter, r, is introduced instead of conventional input oue-dB compression point (PIdBb)a ckoff. Related bit error ratio (BER) -simulated in an AWGN channel with a golden unit receiver model- and EVM (Error Vector Magnitude) discussions are made.

document.title: Copyright
document.abstract: Copyright and Reprint Permissions: Abstracting is permitted with credit to the source. Libraries may photocopy beyond the limits of US copyright law, for private use of patrons, those articles in this volume that carry a code at the bottom of the first page, provided that the per-copy fee indicated in the code is paid through the Copyright Clearance Center. The papers in this book comprise the proceedings of the meeting mentioned on the cover and title page. They reflect the authors' opinions and, in the interests of timely dissemination, are published as presented and without change. Their inclusion in this publication does not necessarily constitute endorsement by the editors or the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

document.title: Transposition of a base band ultra wide band width impulse radio signal at 60 GHz for high data rates multiple access indoor communication systems
document.authors: Deparis, N.; Loyez, C.; Fryziel, M.; Boe, A.; Rolland, N.; Rolland, P.A.
document.abstract: The purpose of this paper is to demonstrate the high potentiality in terms of data rate and multiple access of a novel 60 GHz WLAN architecture for smart objects and indoor Communication systems. This approach is based on the up-conversion of an Ultra Wide Bandwidth Impulse Radio signal (IR-UWB) in the 60 GHz frequency range to benefit of the natural advantages of the UWB technique while avoiding the base band limitations (FCC part 15).

document.title: UMTS WCDMA with smart antennas: hybrid link and system level performance analysis
document.authors: Tsoulos, G.; Kaklamani, D.
document.abstract: This paper presents a hybrid simulation method for the study of the performance of WCDMA with smart antennas. The method combines link level simulations that characterize the performance of the air interface in greater detail, with system level simulations that study the performance of a multi-tier cellular system. After the description of the proposed method, some initial results are provided Cor typical operational scenarios.

document.title: A SiGe HBT variable gain amplifier with 80 dB control range for applications up to 3 GHz
document.authors: Byrne, N.; Murphy, P.J.; McCarthy, K.G.; Foley, B.
document.abstract: A variable eain amplifier suitable for wideband applications (up to 3GHz) has been designed and fabricated in a SiGe BiCMOS process with f<sub>T</sub> = 49 GHz. Variable gain is achieved with a current steering diflerential cascode cell. The amplifier has B linear-io-dB gain range of 82 dB at 1.85 G H a~nd 65 dB at 2.5 GHZw, hich is the largest control ranee reoorted to date. The amolifrer has a maximum gain of 18.<dB, an OIP3 of 7:4 dBm, and a noise figure oi7.5 dB. The chip sue is 1258 km * 1209 pm, and it consumes 39 mA from a 3 V supply. The widehand nature of the VGA makes it suitable for integrated applications incorporating both cellular phone and wireless LAN functionality.

document.title: ECWVT 2004 Sessions
document.abstract: Provides a schedule of conference events and a listing of which papers were presented in each session.

document.title: A truncation method for modelling effective antenna patterns in urban areas
document.authors: Mantel, O.C.; Rijken, M.; Matic, D.; Mawira, A.
document.abstract: Signal level predictions for sector antennas in mobile networks strongly depend on the antenna pattern used in the prediction tool. For built-up areas, reflections and scanering often lead to a significant energy component at the back of the antenna, and the theoretical antenna pattern does not account for this effect. We propose a method that ''truncates" the modelled antenna pattern at the hack of the antenna, such that the Front-To-Back ratio of the pattern becomes smaller. A comparison of the method with memuremen6 shows that this leads to an improved accuracy of the signal level predictions in an urban area.

document.title: Embedded passives design and optimization for quadband EGSM single package RF module
document.authors: Gye-An Lee; Megahed, M.; Agahi, D.; De Flaviis, F.
document.abstract: Novel compact embedded super-diplexer for quadhand GSM RF system is proposed. The design of superdiplexer is based on the performance of cascaded diplexer and lowhigh lowpass fiters. At the same time, low cost compact embedded Tx GSM lowpass filter and diplexer on low cost laminate are designed to replace discrete LTCC lowpass filter and diplexer. The embedded lowpass fiters, diplexer and super-diplexer are built and measurement results show good agreement with the simulation data. The measurement result of super-diplexer is well matched to the cascaded performance of diplexer and lowpass filter. The compactness of the newly developed super-diplexer makes the design and integration of quadhand GSM RF systems attractive for further development and applications in SOC andlor SIP.

document.title: Low complexity dsp implementation of recurrent neural network based multi-user detection
document.authors: Jeney, G.; Pap, L.
document.abstract: In modem multi-user communication systems the role of proper detection handling has gained much importance [3]. The research of multi-user detection started in the late So??s, and developed into a wide coverage scientific field till the end of the century Nowadays the proposed methods are implemented in DSP devices to exploit the performance improvements of multi-user detection in modem mobile communication devices. This paper introduces the idea how to implement the recurrent neural network based detectors with moderate computational complexity. On the one hand the dimension of the network is reduced according to practical considerations. On the other band the applicability of both soft decision function and additional noise sources inside the neurons are analyzed.

document.title: A technique for reducing the PMEPR of MC-CDMA signals
document.authors: Silva, P.; Rui Dinis
document.abstract: In this paper we consider the use of MCCDMA (Multi-Carrier Code Division Multiple Access) schemes with a frequency-domain orthogonal spreading. The transmitter structure is especially modified for reducing the envelope fluctuations of the transmitted signals. An analytical approach for the performance evaluation is also included which relies on the Gaussian characteristics of MC signals with a high number of suhcarriers. A set of performance results is presented. Our performance results show that the proposed transmitter structure is adequate for power-efficient MC-CDMA transmission since we can reduce the envelope fluctuations of the transmitted signals, while keeping essentially the same spectral efficiency of the conventional MC-CDMA transmission.

document.title: Pre-, post-, and combined-equalization single-user bounds for MC-CDMA
document.authors: Cosovic, I.; Schnell, M.; Springer, A.
document.abstract: Considering multi-carrier code-division multiple-access (MC-CDMA) for mobile radio transmission, it is usually assumed that the transmission channel is either known at the MC-CDMA receiver (Rx) or at the MC-CDMA transmitter (Tx). Correspondingly, the inhence of the fading channel is either post-equalized at Rx or pre-equalized at Tx. In this paper, we assume that knowledge of the fading channel is available at both sides, Tx and Rx. Under this assumption we investigate the the MC-CDMA single-user hounds for combined-equalization are derived. It turns out, that application of combined-equalization leads to new single-user hounds, which are signilicantly better than the well-known matched filter (MF) hounds for MC. CDMA. In addition. it is emphasized that the performed analysis and the given bounds are valid for any ortiognnal frequencydivision multiplexiug-code-division multiplexing (OFDM-CDM) based system.

document.title: MMIC based new generation 17 GHz wireles LAN modem
document.authors: Lobeira, M.; Barquinero, U.; Aguero, J.M.; Gonzalez, J.C.; Garcia, J.L.
document.abstract: This paper presents the WIND-FLEX system: a new wireless LAN modem developed in the 17 GHz band. A brief review of the transceiver hardware, which includes the design and development of oscillators, amplifiers and mixers, is included. MMIC devices have been used to implement the RF section of the modem. Characterization of the transceiver and evaluation of the modem performance in an indoor scenario are also summarized in the paper.

document.title: Bottom-up nanoelectronics
document.authors: Hadley, P.
document.abstract: Nanoelectronics is a broad topic that spans molecular devices to silicon field-effect transistors. While the development of nanoscale silicon devices is an important topic, the focus here will be on the challengers to silicon such as molecules, carbon nanotubes, and nanowires. In high performance applications like computation or communications, the challengers might be able to proride devices that are about as fast, and about as small as those that will be made in the near future in silicon. It is not in terms of performance that silicon will be challenged. The real potential of the challengers is that they may eventually provide about the same performance as silicon for a lower price.

document.title: Impact of distributed antenna systems on inter-cell interference
document.authors: Tong, F.; Glover, I.A.; Pennock, S.R.; Shepherd, P.R.
document.abstract: A distributed antenna diversity system can he effective in combating the effects of shadowing, but this results in some antenna units being closer to adjacent cells. Studying this in a free space propagation environment we show that a distributed antenna has marginally worse iutercell interference than a single antenna at the centre of a cell when the total transmission power in the two systems are equal. We also show that the orientation of the distributed antenna influences the inter-cell interference. However, when downlink transmission power is controlled to produce constant signal-to-noise ratio acrass the cell, the distributed antenna system is seen to yield significantly better interference performance than the single antenna system.

document.title: Frequency-agile CMOS RFICs for multi-mode RF front-end
document.authors: Mukhopadhyay, R.; Park, Y.; Lee, C.-H.; Nuttinck, S.; Laskar, J.
document.abstract: This paper presents new reconfigurable RFICs for multi-band applications. It includes a new fully tunable active inductor (TAI) and a frequency-agile VCO implemented using the proposed TAL The ICs have been implemented in 0.18μm CMOS technology. The novelty of the TA1 lies in the use of a tunable feedback resistor that results i n inductances tunable from O.lnH to 15nH with Q>50 for 0.5-3GHz. This new reconfigurable TA1 is used to implement a wideband frequency-agile VCO covering several commercial frequency bands for application in a multi-mode RF frontend. As a proof of concept, a wideband TAI-based VCO has been implemented in 0.18μ CMOS technology. The measured VCO shows an 85.7% tuning range from 500MHz to Z.OGHz. Analysis using theoretical expressions for the new active inductor is also presented.

document.title: An LTCC-based 5-6 GHz receiver with integrated antenna
document.authors: Pergola, L.; Vahldieck, R.; Gobel, U.; Nuchter, P.
document.abstract: We report the design, assembly and measurement of an active RF-frontend module based on LTCC technology. The frontend is part of a 16 element array for a channel sounder operating in the frequency range between 5.15 GHz and 5.875 GHz. The active module includes the antenna, an LNA, a band pass filter for the image rejection and a mixer; a directional coupler is also incorporated for calibration purposes. The measured gain of the module is between 28-34dB over the operating band.

document.title: Introduction to the 2004 European Conference on Wireless Technology (ECWT)
document.abstract: Presents the introductory welcome message from the conference proceedings.

document.title: Simulation studies of interference causing of time jitter in TD-CDMA
document.authors: Maslanka, K.; Gajewski, P.; Hemon, P.
document.abstract: The TD-CDMA technique is one of the modes assumed to use in 3G LJMTS networks. The synchronization error influence on the interference level is discussed for this mode. The simulation model for method validation is described as well as the simulation results are presented in this paper.

document.title: Experimental verification of a ray-launching model used for the prediction of indoor wideband directional radio channel at 5.8 GHz
document.authors: Li, C.; Dolmans, G.; Herben, M.H.A.J.; Martijn, E.F.T.
document.abstract: Space-time communication systems, also known as MIMO systems, make use of temporal and spatial antenna processing techniques to increase capacity and to improve quality-of-services. The processing and combiniug will act locally on these 'closely spaced' MIMO signals; therefore, a local description of the radio channel is necessary. In this paper, the evaluation of a 3D raylaunching tool for the prediction of local radio channel characteristics is presented. For this purpose, spatial channel measurements have been performed indoor at 5.8 GHz. Furthermore, necessary but unknown material dielectric properties have been determined with transmission and reflection measurements. Both line-ofsight and non-line-of-sight cases with different antenna configurations have been studied. Results show a good correspondence between predicted and measured average received power and rms delay spread. For accurate predictions, however, it is important to carefully choose the ray-launching angle step and include detailed environment features such as metallic furniture.

document.title: Dual polarized microstrip patch antenna, reduced in size by use of peripheral slits
document.authors: Notis, D.T.; Liakou, Phaedra C.; Chrissoulidis, D.P.
document.abstract: A two-port, meandered, square, microstrip patch antenna is investigated in this paper. Forty slits are considered on the perimeter of a square patch, ten on each side, to reduce the operating frequency. Calculated and measured results manifest that (a) the gain, the radiation patterns (co- and cross-polar), and the matching microstrip lines are practically unaffected by the peripheral slits, (b) the return loss at both ports is well below -20dB, and (c) the coupling between ports is below -29dB. A square patch, thus meandered, may he up to 48% smaller in area than a square patch without slits, both with the same operating frequency.

document.title: Limits for CPM signals representation by walsh functions
document.authors: Monteiro, F.A.; Rodrigues, A.J.
document.abstract: This paper explores the feasible limits for complexity reduction of a very simple front-end block for the calculus of phase transition metrics on a continuous phase modulation (CPM) receiver. A quasi-optimum receiver of very low complexity is attained by splitting the function of the optimum receiver bank filters in two blocks: calculus of projections coefficients on a low dimensional space of Walsh functions followed by simple matrix calculus. A sequence detection algorithm follows this block The presented approach enables the reductiou of the matched filters or correlators to just two integrators, regardless of the CPM scheme. Research ou the reduction limits of the space dimension is conducted using catastrophic Wary CPM schemes, taking advantage of their very low number of phase states. Performance of lREC h=1/2 16-ary scheme is for the fist time presented. A rule is defined concerning the number of Walsh functions that must be used. That outcome proves to be valid for two CPM schemes of high power gain. The receiver is tested under additive white gaussian noise (AWGN).

document.title: Asymmetric transmission for multimedia application in downlink multi-carrier CDMA channel
document.authors: Hajian, M.; Handoko, D.; Ligthart, L.P.
document.abstract: Multi-carrier CDMA (MC-CDMA) is one of the promising wideband transmission techniques for the fourth generation mobile communication. This paper studies the possibility to improve its performance in the downlink Rayleigh channel by proposing an Adaptive Code Length (ACL) scheme. One of the main reasons for performance degradation is the interference due to the fadingnature of the mobile channel. The ACL scheme has potential to reduce the amount of interference. The performance of the suggested technique has been done analytically and by simulations. A second level of adaptation, threshold adaptation, is also proposed to optimize the performance of the system under various conditions (number of users, Signal to Noise Ratio). ACL is then applied to transmission of two data with diflerent quality denoted as primary and secondary hits. Simulations are done to test the validity of the BER expressions and to further analyze the system behavior:This work is concentrated on Rayleigh fading channeL

document.title: Radio specification and RFIC development for 5.8GHz high rate DSRC
document.authors: Kyung H.Park; Mheen, B.K.; Seong-S.Park
document.abstract: This paper describes a detailed procedure on how to make a radio specification for the system to he employed in a new communication. The radio specification is referred to design RFIC for the system which is 5.8GHz high rate DSRC system. And we show the inter-working test results between the radio module using the RFIC and OFDM modem.

document.title: Compact low-cost 4 elements microstrip antenna array for WLAN
document.authors: Volski, V.; Delmotte, P.; Vandenbosch, G.A.E.
document.abstract: A new 4 element antenna array topology of microstrip E shaped patches for use in WLAN applications is introduced. The operating frequency range is from 3.4 to 3.8 GHz. The array is mounted on a low-cost FR4 substrate and is fed by a standard 50 Ohm coaxial feed. A special combined series I corporate feeding network is incorporated directly in the array. The design chosen makes the array very compact and low cost. The size of the ground plane is 250 by 55 mm only. In the operating frequency range the gain of the array is more than 13 dB and the main beam direction is normal to the ground plane. The array is designed using a fnll wave solver based on the moment method.

document.title: Multi-band base station antenna for diversity and MIMO-applications
document.authors: Pivit, F.; Fischer, G.; Waldschmidt, C.; Wiesbeck, W.
document.abstract: In this paper an antenna element for the application in multi band base station antennas for mobile communication systems is presented. The antenna element covers the most important frequency bands in Europe and Asia (GSM 1800, UMTS at 2100 GHz and UMTS-Plus at 2600 MHz), respects important features regarding manufacturing, signal distribution and signal intermodulation. Since the antenna can be fed independently by two orthogonal feeds, polarization diversity can be realized within a single antenna element. This can be used for polarization diversity and in MIMO systems to adapt the antenna to the channel. The possible system enhancement due to the polarization diversity feature within a single antenna element will be derived.

document.title: Communication technologies-present and future
document.authors: Nair, V.; Sengupta, U.
document.abstract: Future communication devices will have to operate over heterogeneous wireless networks and standards around the world. The dream of a ubiquitous device that provides unhindered connectivity any where at any time is becoming a reality, thanks to the rapid convergence of Computing and communication devices. The emergence of universal mobile devices that encompass computing, communications, entertainment and sensing capabilities will enable the delivery of proactive and context aware applications to highly mobile end-users. However, network heterogeneity brings with it enormous challenges in the design of these mobile devices. This talk will elaborate on the vision, the attributes and technical challenges of future communication systems. In particular advancement of RF component technologies to meet the challenges of the small form factor devices will be described.

document.title: A dual band SiGe quadrature VCO design for GSM/DCS-PCS applications
document.authors: Cordeau, D.; Paillot, J.; De Astis, G.; Dascalescu, L.
document.abstract: A dual hand SiGe fully integrated quadrature Voltage Controlled Oscillator (VCO) for GSM/DCS-PCS applications is presented. This circuit is implemented in a 0.35μ BiCMOS SiGe process and is made of two cross-coupled differential VCOs, with integrated resonator, to ensure the quadrature outputs. At 2.7 V power supply voltage and a total power dissipation of 41.6 mW, the proposed VCO features a worst case phase noise of -8OdBuHz and -96dBr/Hz at IOW and 50kHz frequency offset respectively. Thanks to MOS capacitor switching, the VCO can be tuned over two frequency hands from 1.5 to 2 GHz with a tuning voltage varying from 0 to 2.7v.

document.title: Performance analysis of crosscorrelation predistorters
document.authors: Kokkeler, A.B.J.
document.abstract: Amplification of signals with fluctuating envelopes Leads to distortion because of non-linear behavior of the Power Amplifier (PA). Digital Predistortion can counteract these non-linear effects. A crosscorrelation predistorter is a digital pre-distorter based on the calculation of cross-correlation functions. This cross correlation functions are transformed to the frequency domain and the spectra are used to control the predistorter. In this paper, the crosscorrelation predistorter is described and the performance is given together with the performance of an existing predistorter, the LS predistorter. The crosscorrelation predistorter outperforms the LS predistorter against lower complexity.

document.title: A comparison between free space optics and 70 GHz short haul links behavior based on propagation model and measured data
document.authors: Mandich, D.
document.abstract: Free Space Optic (FSO) has been confirmed as a valid alternative technology [l] that gives the opportunity to implement in a very quick way digital links with capacity up to some hundreds of MBit/sec without the need of license and minimizing installation operations and interference issues. On the other hand we??ve to keep in mind that these systems arc designed to perform , np to some km , in clear weather conditions and , up to now, there is no escape from visibility impairments related to haze, fog, rain, hail and snow. During these phenomena the significant increase of scatter losses can produce unavailability periods that can last some hours in case of fog. On the other hand 70 GHz radio links are mainly affected by rain and snow. The relation between visibility and extinction coefficient ( scatter and absorption losses ) together with its statistical characterization depending on the adopted wavelength are essential for the calculation of an adequate fading margin necessary in order to reach high reliability targets for both the systems.

document.title: The M-algorithm on the detection of CPM schemes on the minimum euclidian distance upper bound
document.authors: Monteiro, F.A.; Rodrigues, A.J.
document.abstract: The impact of the M-algorithm on continuous phase modulation (CPM) detection is analyzed when replacing the common Viterbi algorithm (VA) on the maximum likelihood sequence detection (MLSD) block. The algorithm is presented as a reduced complexity sequence detection algorithm in which not all transitions are propagated, being only retained a small subset of paths. A rule is found concerning the lower limit of the mandatory number of paths to retain, using simulations with additive white gaussian noise (AWGN) when detecting simple catastrophic schemes and two optimum gain schemes, in the sense they are two of the rare coincident with their respective minimum Euclidean upper bounds. The Malgorithm proves near optimum performance for very low ratios of number of traced states per total number of states.

document.title: A novel circularly polarized textile antenna for wearable applications
document.authors: Klemm, M.; Locher, I.; Troster, G.
document.abstract: A novel circularly polarized (CP) textile patch antenna is presented in this paper. To our knowledge, it is the first textile antenna with circular polarization and for the first time, we show that more sophisticated design methods are also applicable to flexible textile antennas. The antenna uses a single inset microstrip feed-line. To achieve proper CP operation, truncated corners along with a single slit in patch are applied. The 3-dB axial-ratio CP bandwidth is about 3%, which represents a very good result eveu compared to standard, bard substrate CP antennas.

document.title: 2.45/5.25-GHz dualband transmitter design
document.authors: Mei-Fen Chou; Wen-An Tsou; Kuei-Ann Wen; Chun-Yen Chang
document.abstract: This paper presents a 2.45/5.25-GHz transmitter equipped with a dualhand load using current combine technique to minimize chip area by sharing inductors for each frequency hand. A systematic design methodology for the current combine load based on parasitic effect considerations is also developed. By following the proposed design procedure, the load inductance and combine capacitance for the dualband transmitter can be easily determined. A 2.45/5.25-GHz CMOS design has heen implemented tu demonstrate the feasibility of the design technique.

document.title: Digital pre-distortion linearizer
document.authors: Virdee, B.S.; Banyamin, B.
document.abstract: First Page of the Article

document.title: A C-band monolithic silicon-bipolar low-power low-IF WLAN receiver
document.authors: Carta, C.; Schmatz, M.; Vogt, R.; Bachtold, W.
document.abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation and measurements of a monolithic low-IF receiver compliant with the main 5GHz WLAN standards. It consists of a low-noise preamplifier, that is simultaneously noise and power matched to the RF source, two matched active single-balanced mixers and two polyphase filters used to generate LO quadrature signals and provide image rejection. Realized in a 47 GHz-<sub>ft</sub> commercial BiCMOS technology, the circuit exhibits 25 dB of conversion gain, 35 dB of IRR, 8.9 dB of NF. -12.5 dBm and -19 dBm of iIP<sus and Plan respectively. To the knowledge of the authors this is the first monolithic implementation of a low-IF C-hand receiver achieving sufficient IRR over the three U-NI1 hands. Power consumption is 19 mW.

document.title: Overview of radio resource management (RRM) issues in multi-radio access systems
document.authors: Jorguseski, L.; Prasad, R.
document.abstract: The concept of multi-radio access networks is currently considered as a strong candidate for the next generation wireless access networks. This concept incorporates conventional cellular networks such as GERAN or UTRAN for wide area coverage while local-area networks such as IEEE 802.11, HIPERLAN/Z, andlor several personal networks (PN) interconnected in ad-hoc fashion are covering the local irafiic hot-spot areas. The new radio access systems that will be developed in the future could also be included in this multi-radio concept because it is diffcult (if not impossible) to design a single wireless access system that optimally works in different I conditions and with different requirements. The radio resource management in multi-radio access networks becomes a very challenging issue. The overall goal of the RRM functions is to optimally utilize the available radio resources and give the users the requested communication quality at affordable cost. Therefore, this paper presents an overview of the most Important RRM issues for multi-radio access networks and gives recommendations for further studies in this field.

document.title: A 900-MHz fully integrated LC-VCO for ISM applications
document.authors: Teichmann, P.; Peter, J.; Laute, A.
document.abstract: In this paper, a fully integrated LC-VCO for FSWASK applications in the 868-MHz and 915-MHz ISM bands is presented. The VCO was realized in a 0.5-pm BiCMOS process with a power metal layer and integrated varactor diodes. For the VCO design, the focus was on simplicity, good bias noise suppression, and a wide supply voltage range. The achieved phase noise level is -99 dBcMz at an offset frequency af 1QQ kHz. The circuit consumes only 1.35 mA from a supply voltage between 1.9 V and 5.5 V. The VCO is controlled with AC-coupled integrated varactor diodes and achieves a tuning range of 160 MHz at a nominal supply voltage of 3 V.

document.title: The prediction of propagation losses in urban areas
document.authors: Wnuk, M.
document.abstract: This paper presents the UTD modified method of calculations of propagation losses in urban areas. This method involves using optic geometry in propagation model and formula used in UTD method for reflection and diffraction wave coefficients. The superposition method is used to calculate resultant field. The calculation algorithm is formed on basis of analyses. In our paper hypothetical calculations are presented.
